unnormalised: The other day, my grandmother, Nirmala Devi, insisted on going to the State Bank of India branch near our house in Patna. She needed to deposit Rs. 25,000 in cash. Despite my repeated attempts to convince her to use UPI – after all, she had learned how to use WhatsApp forwards so quickly – she stubbornly refused. "Beta, nothing beats the feeling of crisp notes," she declared, adjusting her sari.
normalised: The other day, my grandmother, Nirmala Devi, insisted on going to the State Bank of India branch near our house in Patna. She needed to deposit rupee twenty five thousand in cash. Despite my repeated attempts to convince her to use U-P-I – after all, she had learned how to use WhatsApp forwards so quickly – she stubbornly refused. "Beta, nothing beats the feeling of crisp notes," she declared, adjusting her sari.

unnormalised: At the bank, chaos reigned supreme. A long queue snaked its way from the teller counters to the entrance. The security guard, a burly man with a booming voice, kept shouting "Line banao! Line banao!". I looked at the rates board, USD to INR was showing ₹83.50. Nirmala Devi, unfazed, joined the queue behind a gentleman arguing loudly about a bounced cheque. He claimed the bank owed him ₹2,000! The teller, a young woman with tired eyes, tried to explain the charges to him.

Line banao!". I looked at the rates board, U-S-D to I-N-R was showing rupee eighty three point five zero. Nirmala Devi, unfazed, joined the queue behind a gentleman arguing loudly about a bounced cheque. He claimed the bank owed him rupee two thousand! The teller, a young woman with tired eyes, tried to explain the charges to him.

unnormalised: After what felt like an eternity, it was Nirmala Devi’s turn. She carefully counted out 250 notes of ₹100 each, along with 200 notes of ₹50 each, and 20 notes of ₹1000. The teller meticulously verified each note, her fingers flying across the counting machine. Another customer was trying to withdraw 500 USD equivalent. The banking hall felt like a pressure cooker, with everyone impatient to complete their transactions.
normalised: After what felt like an eternity, it was Nirmala Devi’s turn. She carefully counted out two hundred and fifty notes of rupee one hundred each, along with two hundred notes of rupee fifty each, and twenty notes of rupee one thousand. The teller meticulously verified each note, her fingers flying across the counting machine. Another customer was trying to withdraw five hundred U-S-D equivalent. The banking hall felt like a pressure cooker, with everyone impatient to complete their transactions.

unnormalised: Finally, the deposit was made. Nirmala Devi clutched the receipt tightly in her hand, a triumphant smile on her face. We stepped out of the bank, the Patna heat hitting us like a wall. On the way home, she stopped at a sweet shop and bought ₹100 worth of barfi, declaring it a celebration of her successful banking transaction. "See, beta," she said, offering me a piece. "Cash is king! UPI can never replace this satisfaction." I had to smile. Some things, I realised, are just priceless.

unnormalised: Even though I tried explaining the ease of online banking and even showed her how she could send money using her phone to pay her regular vegetable vendor Rs. 350, she wasn't convinced. Grandma Nirmala Devi may be technologically challenged, but she has a lifetime of experience dealing with the tangible world of cash transactions, and she wasn't about to give that up anytime soon. After all, she’s managed her finances perfectly fine since 1947, and a few UPI apps weren't going to change that.
